titleStmt.title: The countrey-mans complaint. Or A true account of the moneys, given, and lent to the Parliament, since the yeer 1640. By William Pryor of Thurning, in the county of Huntington, his means being but 17 l. 10s. a yeer. Together with his losses, crosses, vexations, and imprisonments, by means of the commitees, justices of the county, Lord Mountague of Boudon, and Parson Wells of Thurning. Who with their murthering practises, have endevored (as much as in them lies) the destruction of the said Pryor. Humbly presented to Parliament for justice; to be relieved from his oppressors.
titleStmt.author: Pryor, William.

fileDesc.extent: Approx. 16 KB of XML-encoded text transcribed from 5 1-bit group-IV TIFF page images.

titleStmt.title: The countrey-mans complaint. Or A true account of the moneys, given, and lent to the Parliament, since the yeer 1640. By William Pryor of Thurning, in the county of Huntington, his means being but 17 l. 10s. a yeer. Together with his losses, crosses, vexations, and imprisonments, by means of the commitees, justices of the county, Lord Mountague of Boudon, and Parson Wells of Thurning. Who with their murthering practises, have endevored (as much as in them lies) the destruction of the said Pryor. Humbly presented to Parliament for justice; to be relieved from his oppressors.

projectDesc.p: Created by converting TCP files to TEI P5 using tcp2tei.xsl, TEI @ Oxford.

editorialDecl.p: EEBO-TCP is a partnership between the Universities of Michigan and Oxford and the publisher ProQuest to create accurately transcribed and encoded texts based on the image sets published by ProQuest via their Early English Books Online (EEBO) database (http://eebo.chadwyck.com). The general aim of EEBO-TCP is to encode one copy (usually the first edition) of every monographic English-language title published between 1473 and 1700 available in EEBO.

EEBO-TCP aimed to produce large quantities of textual data within the usual project restraints of time and funding, and therefore chose to create diplomatic transcriptions (as opposed to critical editions) with light-touch, mainly structural encoding based on the Text Encoding Initiative (http://www.tei-c.org).

The EEBO-TCP project was divided into two phases. The 25,368 texts created during Phase 1 of the project (2000-2009), initially available only to institutions that contributed to their creation, were released into the public domain on 1 January 2015. The approximately 40,000 texts produced during Phase 2 (2009- ), of which 34,963 had been released as of 2020, originally similarly restricted, were similarly freed from all restrictions on 1 August 2020. As of that date anyone is free to take and use these texts for any purpose (modify them, annotate them, distribute them, etc.). But we do respectfully request that due credit and attribution be given to their original source.
Users should be aware of the process of creating the TCP texts, and therefore of any assumptions that can be made about the data.

Text selection was based on the New Cambridge Bibliography of English Literature (NCBEL). If an author (or for an anonymous work, the title) appears in NCBEL, then their works are eligible for inclusion. Selection was intended to range over a wide variety of subject areas, to reflect the true nature of the print record of the period. In general, first editions of a works in English were prioritized, although there are a number of works in other languages, notably Latin and Welsh, included and sometimes a second or later edition of a work was chosen if there was a compelling reason to do so.

Image sets were sent to external keying companies for transcription and basic encoding. Quality assurance was then carried out by editorial teams in Oxford and Michigan. 5% (or 5 pages, whichever is the greater) of each text was proofread for accuracy and those which did not meet QA standards were returned to the keyers to be redone. After proofreading, the encoding was enhanced and/or corrected and characters marked as illegible were corrected where possible up to a limit of 100 instances per text. Any remaining illegibles were encoded as <gap>s. Understanding these processes should make clear that, while the overall quality of TCP data is very good, some errors will remain and some readable characters will be marked as illegible. Users should bear in mind that in all likelihood such instances will never have been looked at by a TCP editor.
The texts were encoded and linked to page images in accordance with level 4 of the TEI in Libraries guidelines.

Copies of the texts have been issued variously as SGML (TCP schema; ASCII text with mnemonic sdata character entities); displayable XML (TCP schema; characters represented either as UTF-8 Unicode or text strings within braces); or lossless XML (TEI P5, characters represented either as UTF-8 Unicode or TEI g elements).
Keying and markup guidelines are available at the Text Creation Partnership web site.

div.p: OR A true Account of the Moneys, given, and lent to the PARLIAMENT, Å¿ince the yeer 1640. By William Pryor of Thurning, in the County of Huntington, His Means being but 17 l. 10 s. a yeer.
Together with his LoÅ¿Å¿es, CroÅ¿Å¿es, Vexations, and ImpriÅ¿onments, by means of the Commitees, JuÅ¿tices of the County, Lord Mountague of Boudon, and ParÅ¿on Wells of Thurning.
Who with their Murthering PractiÅ¿es, have endevored (as much as in them lies) the deÅ¿truction of the Å¿aid Pryor.
Humbly preÅ¿ented to Parliament for JuÅ¿tice; to be relieved from his OppreÅ¿Å¿ors.

q.p: Execute judgment in the morning, and deliver him that u Å¿poiled out of the hands of the oppreÅ¿Å¿or, leÅ¿t my fury go out like fire, and burn that none quench it, becauÅ¿e of the evil of your doings.

div.head: A true account of the moneys given, and lent to the Parliament, Å¿ince the yeer 1640. by William Pryor of Thurning, in the County of Huntington, together with the loÅ¿Å¿es, croÅ¿Å¿es, vexations, and impriÅ¿onments undergone by the Å¿aid William Pryor, by the means of the Committees of Huntington, by JuÅ¿tices of the County; who with their deÅ¿tructive practices, have endevored (as much as in them lie) the deÅ¿truction of the Å¿aid Pryor, as will appear by this enÅ¿uing Catalogue.
div.p: HIs means is worth by eÅ¿timation, but 17 l. 10 s. per annum.

1. Lent upon the PropoÅ¿itions, in HorÅ¿e, Money, and Plate, 6 l. paid towards HorÅ¿es charged 14 s. 3 d. paid for the Scotch Army 12 s. paid for the BritiÅ¿h Army in Ireland 1 l. 1 s. 6 d. paid for the EngliÅ¿h Army 16 l. 1 s. 6 d. paid towards the preÅ¿Å¿ing and Å¿etting out of Souldiers; and for maimed Souldiers, Widows, and Orphans, of Å¿uch as were Å¿lain in the Parliament Å¿ervice, 7 s. 4. d. paid towards Voluntiers, and Bulworks making 9 s. paid to the Committees for fines and amercements, though he himÅ¿elf appeared with HorÅ¿e, and Arms 1 l. 6 s. 7 d. paid towards the maintenance of the EaÅ¿tern GarriÅ¿ons, for disbanding Foot and Dragoons, and paying them a moneths pay 12 s. 6 d. for reducing of Newark 2 s. towards paying the Kingdoms debts 1 l. 7 s. SubÅ¿idy 1640 & 1641. 1 l. 4 s. Poll money 3 s. Contribution
and Loan for Ireland 9 s. Carriages taken and impreÅ¿Å¿ed 3 s.
II. LoÅ¿Å¿es by the Cavaliers, viz Two HorÅ¿es worth 18 l. and a Gelding with Bridles and Saddles, and himÅ¿elf taken priÅ¿oner, to his damage 8 l. and a Mare worth 6 l.

III. Towards the raiÅ¿ing of recrute for the Army at Saint Ives 17 l. given at the Å¿aid time three HorÅ¿es for the Å¿ervice, worth 20 l. Å¿pent upon five Alarms at Huntington, 5 l. Å¿pent in the Å¿ervice at the Lord Generals firÅ¿t going out of London, 2 l. Å¿pent in Å¿eting his Å¿on out of priÅ¿on 3 l.
div.q: Sufferings by the Committee of Huntington.
div.p: IV. Had his Arms Å¿eiÅ¿ed upon, viz. A Å¿word and Fowling Peeceâª with a Pocket PiÅ¿tol (which was none of his) and was forced to redeem them out of the Committees Agents hands, and to return the PiÅ¿tol home again, he borrowing it onely to aÅ¿Å¿iÅ¿t Lieutenant General Cromwel againÅ¿t Burley, and afterwards, the Committee under pretence of Å¿ending for Cavaliers Arms, Å¿ent for his; and becauÅ¿e the PiÅ¿tol was wanting, (being none of his) he going along with them to Huntington, was five days impriÅ¿oned by the Committee, for not delivering up that (which was not his) to his damage (it being in the midÅ¿t of Seed time, and he having no body to follow his buÅ¿ineÅ¿s) in his Crop at HarveÅ¿t 10 l. beÅ¿ides his expense in priÅ¿on, and in promoting a Petition to the Earl of MancheÅ¿ter; notwithÅ¿tanding at the Å¿ame time, they left Cavaliers Arms hanging behinde the door unÅ¿eiÅ¿ed upon, although they were told of them.

V. After this, he was Å¿ummoned before Mr. CaÅ¿tle, one of Committee, and Mr. Bernard of Huntington, by Warrant, he appearing, it was demanded of him, Why he would not pay what was due to Mr. Wells, ParÅ¿on; he anÅ¿wered, He owed him nothing; and if the ParÅ¿on thought that he owed him any thing, the Law, and the ordinary Courts of JuÅ¿tice, were all open, when he Å¿hould be ready to joyn iÅ¿Å¿ue with him; to which, the JuÅ¿tices replyed, That there was an Ordinance of Parliament to enforce the payment of Tithes; but he denyed that he owed him any thing. To that Mr. Bernard anÅ¿wered, That Tithes was due by Scripture, inÅ¿tancing that
Scripture, That thou Å¿halt not muzzle the mouth of the Ox that treadeth out the Corn: To which he replyed, He was none of his Ox, neither did he tred out any of his Corn. Whereupon, the JuÅ¿tices deÅ¿iÅ¿t at preÅ¿ent, and ParÅ¿on Wells got a Writ, and arreÅ¿ted the Å¿aid Pryor; upon which, he offered the common bayl, which them Bailiff refuÅ¿ed, Å¿ayjng, They muÅ¿t have two SubÅ¿idy men bound, or elÅ¿e he muÅ¿t to priÅ¿on; and upon the Å¿ame, carried him away from his buÅ¿ineÅ¿s (Cattle getting to his Reek of Grain, by reaÅ¿on of his abÅ¿ence) to his damage 1 l. And being drawn away by Cavaliers Bailiffs, in a moÅ¿t horrid maner, beating, punching, and dragging him through the dirt to priÅ¿on, where he continued fourteen hours, to his damage 1 l. And procuring two men to be bound, was releaÅ¿ed, and appeared by his Atturney at the next Term; yet notwithÅ¿tanding his bayl was arreÅ¿ted in a moÅ¿t unjuÅ¿t maner, for not appearing upon which, he was forced to go to London, in HarveÅ¿t, to Å¿earch the Records, whether there was any neglect in his Atturney, which be found contrary, to his damage 7 l. After this, the ParÅ¿on lets the Å¿uit fall, and goeth to the Committee for a Warrant to diÅ¿train; upon which, the two forementioned JuÅ¿tices grant him a Warrant contrary to their Oaths, contrary to the Liberty of the Subject, contrary to the 29 Chapter of Magna Charta (the EngliÅ¿h mans Birthright) to break open any Doors, or Gates, to Å¿eiÅ¿e upon any Goods (as they that came to diÅ¿train, did declare.)
The Bailiffs that came to diÅ¿train, was MaÅ¿Å¿er of Luddington, and Wolman of Oundle, one of Major Butlers Souldiers.

When they firÅ¿t came into the yard, they asked for him. It was replyed, He was gone from home; whereupon they Å¿aid, He did ow Mr. Wells money, and they came to diÅ¿train; and preÅ¿ently fell to driving away Cattle, and they drove away eight Cows, and Bullocks, worth 2 â¢ . l. but his wife, with thoÅ¿e at home, endevored to reÅ¿iÅ¿t, Å¿aying, They came like theeves (Å¿he demanding their Warrant, wch they refuÅ¿ed to produce) the aforeÅ¿aid MaÅ¿Å¿er run at her with his Å¿word, Å¿wearing he would run her through; upon which, Å¿he not Å¿tirring, he Å¿triks her, thruÅ¿ts her into a ditch, calling her whore, and preÅ¿ently
drove the Cattle out of the County, which they ought not to have done by the Statute, and Å¿etting Malignants to prize them, and Å¿old them unto their (and the Parliaments) utter enemies, within a day or two, when as they Å¿hould have been unfold fifteen days, which was to his damage (by going to London, and many other places in HarveÅ¿t time. The want of Milk, Butter, and CheeÅ¿e, for his Family (beÅ¿ides the worth of the BeaÅ¿ts) 20 l.

FirÅ¿t, He demanded Tithes of the Å¿aid Pryor for three Acres of Land, which he hath in the Lord Mountagues liberties; he pleaded he owed him none, Å¿aying, That which he had formerly practiÅ¿ed, was a denying ChriÅ¿t to be come in the fleÅ¿h; in general, denying the three offices of ChriÅ¿t, in particular, againÅ¿t three Articles of the National Covenant, and againÅ¿t the Law of the Land; all which particulars, he made appear, That his LordÅ¿hip and his Chaplain had little to Å¿ay. Moreover, He told his LordÅ¿hip, if he had offended him he Å¿hould Å¿atisfie himÅ¿elf out of his Land; telling his LordÅ¿hip, That if he would demand the Free-Å¿imple of one of his Lands, he would not withÅ¿tand him; but for Tithes his ConÅ¿cience bound him to withÅ¿tand him: Whereupon his LordÅ¿hip was pleaÅ¿ed to cauÅ¿e him to be arreÅ¿ted forcing him to put in Bond of 40 l. to appear in perÅ¿on at London, which according to the Law, he could not demand, keeping him four hours in priÅ¿on, while he gave in that Bond, by which they forced him to Å¿tay all the Term, at London, at great expences, waiting upon his LordÅ¿hips Declaration, which he did not deliver in that time, it being co his damage 10 l. And the Å¿aid Pryor, by reaÅ¿on of the corruption of the Lawyers, in cleaving to thoÅ¿e that have biggeÅ¿t purÅ¿e, and to dance after great mens pipes, by reaÅ¿on of whoÅ¿e influenced together with the Law-Monopolizers, the poor mans cauÅ¿e cannot be heard, nor Lawyers gotten to plead for him, which was his caÅ¿e: his Lawyer he got neglected his buÅ¿ineÅ¿s, Å¿o that his LordÅ¿hip got Judgment againÅ¿t him; which he hearing of, went up to London the next Term, and made Affidavit, and Å¿o Å¿tayed Execution, which
was to his loÅ¿s by time and money the value of 7 l. And afterward, he committed his buÅ¿ineÅ¿s to a Lawyer of Lincolns Inn, one Mr. FoÅ¿ter, he being not able to Å¿tay at London to follow his buÅ¿ineÅ¿s, which Lawyer neglected his buÅ¿ineÅ¿s, and Å¿o his LordÅ¿hip had execution; which he moÅ¿t violently, unreaÅ¿onably, and unworthily proÅ¿ecuted againÅ¿t him, taking away for one yeers Tithes, more goods then the Free-Å¿imple of the Land is worth; taking away three BeaÅ¿ts, worth 15 l. for one yeers Tithes of that Land, which is worth but (according to the rate of that Land lying by it, even three Acres and a half) 11 s. 8 d. per annum.

Neither did his LordÅ¿hip yet ceaÅ¿e his murthering, tyrannical practices, towards the Å¿aid Pryor, but cauÅ¿ed his HorÅ¿e to be pounded off his own ground by his Tenants, locking them to a poÅ¿t up to the Feet-locks in dirt, to deÅ¿troy them, forcing him to reprieve them Å¿everal times, not onely to the Å¿poiling his HorÅ¿es, but hindering him in his buÅ¿ineÅ¿s, in Tilling his Land, to his damage 40 l. Afterwards, forcing him to try his Title for his own-ground, the which being almoÅ¿t brought to a tryal in the Country, his LordÅ¿hip removed it to London, on purpoÅ¿e to make him to Å¿pend money, that if poÅ¿Å¿ible, he might deÅ¿troy him; yet this cruel tyrant doth not reÅ¿t here, but cauÅ¿eth the Å¿aid Pryor to be arreÅ¿ted the Å¿econd time; and leaÅ¿t he Å¿hould finde out an honeÅ¿t Lawyer (which is hard to finde) he chooÅ¿eth him one himÅ¿elf, and forceth him to imploy him (and many other evils) which if they Å¿hould be mentioned, it would be much more labor to relate what the Å¿aid Pryor hath Å¿uffered by this Tyrant, alias Lord.

I Å¿hall onely mention one thing more, in relation to the Title of the Land, viz. His LordÅ¿hip having Agents abroad, to perÅ¿wade men equally concerned with the Å¿aid Pryor, not to joyn with him, for his LordÅ¿hip would hot meddle with them, onely he was minded to tire out the Å¿aid Pryor, witneÅ¿s ParÅ¿on Wells his Å¿peaking to Thomas Smith of Warmington, and MaÅ¿Å¿er of Luddington to William Collings of Thurning. His LordÅ¿hips tyranny, and injuÅ¿ticeâª towards the Å¿aid Pryor, hath, and doth occaÅ¿ion, and continually incourage Delinquents,
and ill-affected, to Parliament and Army, his LordÅ¿hip Å¿iding with them, That they make it a matter of nothing to worry his Cattle to death; Å¿trike others with Forks, and break their backs. Sometimes they break up his cloÅ¿e Hedges, other times his Gates, putting in their Cattle, cutting his HorÅ¿e Ropes in the Field, to his intolerable prejudice, and vexation. TheÅ¿e with many other, are his daily Å¿ufferings, beÅ¿ides his
â¢ ears he receiveth by his (and the Parliament, and Armies) enemies, telling him, he will be for the Parliament again, they are his good MaÅ¿ters, how mightily they protect him! other times, if they can take him at an advantage, they drag him in to drink the Kings health: It is impoÅ¿Å¿ible to reckon up his loÅ¿Å¿es, croÅ¿Å¿es, vexations, and impriÅ¿onments, that he hath Å¿uffered for Å¿tanding up to maintain the peoples Liberties in Parliament; beÅ¿ides that, twelve yeers being in the CommiÅ¿Å¿aries Courts, for not being Å¿ubject to Å¿ome of their Orders, before this Parliament began, being in continual vexations by the BiÅ¿hops Declarations, by Summers, Procters, Informers, and other of that beaÅ¿tly vermine, &c.

div.head: PoÅ¿tÅ¿cript.
div.p: GEntle Reader, Thou haÅ¿t here preÅ¿ented unto thee a Catalogue of evils, undergone by the Å¿aid William Pryor; by which it doth appear (that notwithÅ¿tanding the Reformation that is in the Nation, Å¿ince this Parliament) there yet remain great and intolerable oppreÅ¿Å¿ions, upon Å¿ome particular perÅ¿ons, who without the Parliaments great care, to protect, and defend, in relieving them (according to their promiÅ¿es, being their, and the Kingdoms faithful Friends) they are like to be deÅ¿troyed, not onely by their, and the Parliaments enemies, but by pretended friends, as appeareth by this man, whoÅ¿e whole EÅ¿tate was worth by eÅ¿timation, but 17 1. 10 s. per anuum, as aforeÅ¿aid: and out of that Å¿mall EÅ¿tate hath dis â¢ urÅ¿t freely by gift and Taxes, 76 l. 6 s. 1 d. and beÅ¿ides that, hath had unjuÅ¿tly taken from him, as he is able to prove, 163 l. 6 s. 7 d. being in all, the juÅ¿t Å¿um of 239 l. 12 s. 8 d. which is to the full two thirds of his EÅ¿tate.
